summary: “Gendry,” she called, her voice low and urgent. “They have a boat. We could sail the rest of the way up to Riverrun. It would be...
text:
Gendry,” she called, her voice low and urgent. “They have a boat. We could sail the rest of the way up to Riverrun. It would be faster than riding, I think.”
He looked dubious. “Did you ever sail a boat?”
“You put up the sail,” she said, “and the wind pushes it.”
“What if the wind is blowing the wrong way?”
“Then there’s oars to row.”
“Against the current?” Gendry frowned. “Wouldn’t that be slow? And what if the boat tips over and we fall into the water? It’s not our boat anyway, it’s the inn’s.”
We could take it. Arya chewed her lip and said nothing. They dismounted in front of stables. There were no other horses to be seen, but Arya noticed fresh manure in many of the stalls. “One of us should watch the horses,” she said, wary.
Tom overheard her. “There’s no need for that, Squab. Come eat, they’ll be safe enough.”
“I’ll stay,” Gendry said, ignoring the singer. “You can come get me after you’ve had some food.

blog.name: fedonciadale
blog.title: FedonCiadale
blog.description: Fantasy aficionado since I read Tolkien in my teenage years. I still love Tolkien but I am also into other works. I love ASOIAF (books) and GoT (Show). I also like Brandon Sanderson, Lois McMaster Bujold, in short in my free time it's fantasy...Header by courtesy of ragekitn!

summary: To go South - chapter 46 - The knot tightens
title: To go South - chapter 46 - The knot tightens
body:
Arya prepares for the last battle against the White Walkers. She hasn’t found her place yet, and is filled with dread. Also on AO3.

First thing in the morning, Arya looked for Gendry, but he was already at the forge, helping out with doing some last reparations. His face had a concentrated look, but he seemed to feel her gaze. He looked up and smiled, but soon bent his head over the forge again. Arya knew, she should not distract him. Reluctantly she left him to mind his business.

On her way out, she almost ran into the Dragon queen. She bowed and said “Your grace” like a proper subject. She wondered what Daenerys wanted in the forge. Jon had flown out scouting checking if Bran’s estimate of the arrival of the army of the dead was right, but not Daenerys.

It seemed like everyone had something important to do. Sansa drove them all relentlessly during the whole day, Ghost a permanent presence at her side. Food was transported into the crypts, to last them for a few days. Samwell, the fat black brother, and Maester Wolkan were told to take care for the medicine and Gilly and other mothers invented a play for the children, so they would know to run fast for the crypts. Brienne went through the motions with the soldiers twice, and only stopped when it was her time to guard Sansa. That old man Ser Davos directed the men who distributed the wildfire.

Arya became increasingly nervous over the day. A sense of dread threatened to enclose her which she had not felt before the last battle. Somehow last time, when the White Walkers had come it had been easier. Now she knew what awaited them, and although the plan was set, her heart was heavy. She was trying to make up her mind, where her place would be. She felt out of place and for the first time in weeks she was tempted to take one of her faces and do some spying. She knew it was no use. She had no face that would be blend in with the Dothraki and she had no idea of the language, not to mention the Unsullied.

In between she went to Gendry at the forge. He was busy every time, there was an endless string of men who wanted last minute repairs, many of them Unsullied. Arya brought him something to eat, so he would not have to interrupt his work. That was at least something useful and she felt a bit better. They chatted for a while, Gendry munching happily on the bread she had brought. She wished this day would never end, she wished it was the next day already, or the day after that. Then I will know, if I’ll be dead. She might not know of course. She tried to squeeze some laughter into the remaining hours, and she gladly listened to Gendry telling her about how he had actually run the City watch in King’s Landing. For half an hour she forgot her worries and she chuckled happily at the image of Cersei being duped into trusting a bastard son of King Robert. Gendry went back to work, and it was her time to tell. Arya was reluctant to share all her adventures, but she told Gendry how Sansa and herself had taken down Littlefinger.

Her mood soured when Daenerys came to the forge. Again! This time, she was accompanied by the pretty girl that had stood by her side on the field. The Unsullied immediately stood to attention. Daenerys didn’t seem to have a real purpose in being there. She strolled idly through the room, picking up some items and discarding them. Her eyes kept coming back to Gendry though and she gave him a dazzling smile, that filled Arya’s belly with smoldering heat of annoyance. Why does she smile so smug? She exchanged a few words with Gendry and introduced him to the Unsullied. She already knows who he is, what is this all about? Suddenly, Arya could not bear it any longer. She jumped up, took her leave with a barely muttered “your Grace” and stormed off.

She went in search for Sansa, who was in her room and let herself in after a bare knock. Brienne greeted her with a snarl. Her hand was on the hilt of her sword. Ghost trotted over, rubbed himself at her calves but took up his silent vigil at Sansa’s side again. Arya rubbed her eyes. I will not cry.

It was no use, Sansa took her hand and she blurted it all out. That she felt useless, that she hated Daenerys, that she was afraid to die, afraid to survive, only to lose everyone else, that Bran made no sense half of the time and that Daenerys had ogled Gendry. The last was out before she could stop herself and she felt the blood rush to her cheeks.

“It is just… I am so nervous. Half of the time, I don’t know what I am saying. Gendry is my friend, I don’t want her near him, with her smug smile. She is up to something. I just know it.”

Sansa had listened and her face became serious.

“Do you think Daenerys knows, that Gendry is King Robert’s son? I was careful not to mention it, but someone else might have told her.”

She looked at Brienne. “I try to avoid her as much as I can. But with his looks you wouldn’t even need to be told.”

Arya’s heart skipped a beat.

“But he is just a bastard? Surely, she can’t think that this means anything.”

“What exactly did she do?”

Arya took a calming breath and told Sansa everything she remembered and then it dawned on her.

“She was making sure her Unsullied know who he is,” she whispered.

Sansa nodded.

A cold hand extended its clammy fingers over Arya’s heart.

“Daenerys might think that one more or less man who falls in the battle will not be questioned,” Brienne said. “Maybe we should guard him.”

Yes, guard him. Arya wanted to shout, but she knew that Brienne would be among the fighters this night.

“You’ll do that Arya,” Sansa said. “Just keep close to him. We might be mistaken, and Daenerys just wanted to make sure that her Unsullied have good armour.”

Arya scoffed. “Not very likely. She doesn’t strike me as someone who looks after her men’s armour personally.”

Sans took her sister’s hand. “Or do you want me to take Gendry with me? Brienne says I could use more guards.”

Arya shook her head. “He probably wouldn’t want that.”

There was a short knock and Jon entered. He went to Sansa in long strides and took her in his arms. His murmurs were too low for Arya to understand. He pressed himself to her as if he never wanted to let go. Then he abruptly stepped back.

“Gods bless you, Sansa. I hope we’ll see dawn.”

“We are prepared, Jon. We did everything we could. Now, we have to survive this night.”

She took his face in her hands and kissed him fully on the lips. Arya looked away and studied her toes.

Jon turned to Brienne. “I trust you have enough guards for the Queen.”

Brienne nodded. Jon turned to Arya and ruffled her hair.

“Will you stay with Sansa?”

“I’ll fight.” Arya said.

Jon studied her. “Just be careful.”

He sighed. “We’d better do a speech to motivate people, before I am off on Rhaegal again. We have an hour if not less. Will you join me?” He exended his hand.

Sansa let her hand linger for a moment on the cover of her bed, as if she had a fond memory she wanted to salvage. But when she left the room with Jon at her side, she did not look back. Neither did Arya. Her dread stayed with her, but suddenly her fear had a name, and she knew what she would do. She would ensure that Gendry stayed alive. Just to spite you Dragon queen. If you think you can take my friend, you’d better think again.

“What exactly did she do?”

Arya took a calming breath and told Sansa everything she remembered and then it dawned on her.

“She was making sure her Unsullied know who he is,” she whispered.

Sansa nodded.

A cold hand extended its clammy fingers over Arya’s heart.

“Daenerys might think that one more or less man who falls in the battle will not be questioned,” Brienne said. “Maybe we should guard him.”

Yes, guard him. Arya wanted to shout, but she knew that Brienne would be among the fighters this night.

“You’ll do that Arya,” Sansa said. “Just keep close to him. We might be mistaken, and Daenerys just wanted to make sure that her Unsullied have good armour.”

Arya scoffed. “Not very likely. She doesn’t strike me as someone who looks after her men’s armour personally.”

Sans took her sister’s hand. “Or do you want me to take Gendry with me? Brienne says I could use more guards.”

Arya shook her head. “He probably wouldn’t want that.”

There was a short knock and Jon entered. He went to Sansa in long strides and took her in his arms. His murmurs were too low for Arya to understand. He pressed himself to her as if he never wanted to let go. Then he abruptly stepped back.

“Gods bless you, Sansa. I hope we’ll see dawn.”

“We are prepared, Jon. We did everything we could. Now, we have to survive this night.”

She took his face in her hands and kissed him fully on the lips. Arya looked away and studied her toes.

Jon turned to Brienne. “I trust you have enough guards for the Queen.”

Brienne nodded. Jon turned to Arya and ruffled her hair.

“Will you stay with Sansa?”

“I’ll fight.” Arya said.

Jon studied her. “Just be careful.”

He sighed. “We’d better do a speech to motivate people, before I am off on Rhaegal again. We have an hour if not less. Will you join me?” He exended his hand.

Sansa let her hand linger for a moment on the cover of her bed, as if she had a fond memory she wanted to salvage. But when she left the room with Jon at her side, she did not look back. Neither did Arya. Her dread stayed with her, but suddenly her fear had a name, and she knew what she would do. She would ensure that Gendry stayed alive. Just to spite you Dragon queen. If you think you can take my friend, you’d better think again.
trail.content_abstract:
Arya prepares for the last battle against the White Walkers. She hasn’t found her place yet, and is filled with dread. Also on AO3.

First thing in the morning, Arya looked for Gendry, but he was already at the forge, helping out with doing some last reparations. His face had a concentrated look, but he seemed to feel her gaze. He looked up and smiled, but soon bent his head over the forge again. Arya knew, she should not distract him. Reluctantly she left him to mind his business.

summary: I'm totally just being petty because I saw a comment on the contrary, but I'll leave this right here for future reference if...
body:
I’m totally just being petty because I saw a comment on the contrary, but I’ll leave this right here for future reference if anyone says Sansa never called Arya horse face.

“She bit her lip, groping for another name. Lommy had called her Lumpyhead, Sansa used Horseface, and her father’s men once dubbed her Arya Underfoot, but she did not think any of those were the sort of name he wanted.”

ACOK- Arya IX

summary: I hope after seeing GOT S8, it lights a fire under GRRM's ass to finish TWOW asap and start writing ADOS. We can't be left with...
body: I hope after seeing GOT S8, it lights a fire under GRRM’s ass to finish TWOW asap and start writing ADOS. We can’t be left with D&D’s version of Arya and Bran. It would be horrible if the show’s ending it’s the only one we got. They deserve better and we deserve better than the crap the show has dished out. They are 2 of the series main characters and are treated like 2nd and 3rd tier characters.

summary: Concept: Game Of Thrones ASOUE AU
body:
Concept: Game Of Thrones ASOUE AU

Arya, Bran and Rickon Stark have lived very pleasant lives so far, in a lovely house with their loving parents. The three children are intelligent and talented in the arts of invention, reading and biting, respectively. All in all, they live great lives, and there’s no reason for them to not continue to do so.

At least, until a fire breaks out at Winterfell Mansion, where the Stark family lives. This fire claims the lives of Eddard and Catelyn Stark, and leaves their children orphaned and homeless.

With their finances in the hands of Mr. Tyrell, a banker of questionable usefulness, the three orphans are packed off to live with a distant relative, Count Petyr. Count Petyr is a dreadful actor with a troupe of dreadful cohorts, and a sinister plan to claim the Stark fortune.

After his scheme is foiled, the Starks are passed on to a string of other locations- including Uncle Syrio, a Braavosi herpetologist they’ve never met, who offers a brief period of happiness for the children, Aunt Lysa, an unstable, grammar-obsessed widow, who has lived alone in a crumbling old house known as the Eyrie ever since the death of her husband and son, and, strangely, a lumber mill.

At every turn, though, Count Petyr and his cohorts turn up in disguise, Mr. Tyrell fails to be of any use, and the same questions are raised again and again. Why did the Stark mansion burn down? What is the connection between the guardians the children are placed under? Who is Count Petyr, and why is he so awful? And who is the narrator of this tragic tale, Tyrion Lannister? How does he fit into all of this?

tags: stop sleeping on certain parts of her
summary: Is it bad I'm a little bitter that some fans think that Arya's only use is as a protector or a fighter? More specifically they...
body:
Is it bad I’m a little bitter that some fans think that Arya’s only use is as a protector or a fighter? More specifically they think her story is just leading up to her serving in a queensguard even though she is proven to be one of the smartest people in Westeros, being able to keep up with TYWIN LANNISTER and commanding respect from him as a young child. Not to mention is one of the only highborns in the story to truly love and appreciate the smallfolk and is the only one who has lived amongst them.

Thank you that is all. Thank you for coming to my Ted Talk. F whoever thinks that she wouldn’t be good at running a household, castle, or a kingdom, or couldn’t learn how to be politically savvy.
